reasoning: The critique targets the paper’s multiplicative ‘product of factors’ toy model (Sec 2.4) and its assumptions (independence, distributional form, empirical/falsifiable grounding). That model is a meaningful support for the ‘eutopian fragility’ intuition, so the attack is moderately central. But much of the paper’s overall “no easy eutopia / most plausible views are fussy” case also rests on non-multiplicative considerations (lists of moral-catastrophe dimensions, plus the bounded/unbounded scaling arguments in Sec 3), so refuting the multiplicative model would not collapse the position. The critique is partly correct that the toy model doesn’t establish causal independence or justify uniform sampling and doesn’t yield straightforward empirical predictions; however it overclaims that the paper’s “core argument” becomes unfalsifiable or loses “all empirical grounding,” since the paper presents the product model explicitly as a toy/illustrative model and offers additional argument strands. It is clear, focused, and contains little to no dead weight.
title: The multiplicative model lacks empirical grounding and falsifiable predictions
